speaker: therapist
text: Aah! Alex.

speaker: client_1
text: Paul.

speaker: client_1
text: So, are there any rules?

speaker: therapist
text: Rules? Ground rules.

speaker: client_1
text: Anything I should know before we start?

speaker: therapist
text:
Oh -- not really. It's more or less, uh --
it's more or less up to you.

speaker: client_1
text: Oh, right, right.

speaker: client_1
text: I'm a customer.

speaker: therapist
text: Yeah.

speaker: client_1
text:
Though, in my profession, we say
that the customer is always wrong.

speaker: therapist
text: That's a... that's a therapist joke.

speaker: client_1
text: So, do you recognize me?

speaker: therapist
text: No.

speaker: client_1
text: I'm sorry, should, uh... should I?

speaker: client_1
text:
Well, I was told you're the best.
A man in tune with everything around him,
so, yes, I guess you should.

speaker: therapist
text:
Thank you, but I, I, I do think
that in this profession, the "the best" is really a matter of... personal opinion.

speaker: therapist
text: I don't know, the best can be established by facts -- and figures.

speaker: client_1
text: You're the best. I did my research.

speaker: client_1
text: A couple former patients, someone else who knew you from graduate school.

speaker: client_1
text: Does that pressure you? Is it important for you to know that... I am... the best?

speaker: therapist
text: Yes.

speaker: client_1
text: It's nothing personal. I always go to the best. Dentists, mechanics.

speaker: client_1
text: You know what they say: "Save now, pay later."

speaker: client_1
text: So what do you think, being... "the best" therapist entails? Do you recognize me?

speaker: therapist
text: No. I... I... I don't.

speaker: client_1
text: Okay, let me help you. "The Madrasah Murderer." Does that mean anything to you?

speaker: therapist
text: No.

speaker: client_1
text: Wasn't that long ago.

speaker: client_1
text: A US Navy aircraft hit a target on the outskirts of Baghdad. Naval intelligence identified the structure as an insurgent safe house. A bunker. Turns out it's a madrasah.

speaker: client_1
text: Let me tell you what that is. It's an Islamic religion school. Boys like bees in a beehive, studying the Koran. 16 of them -- dead.

speaker: therapist
text: Rings a bell?

speaker: client_1
text: Yes, I remember that, yes.

speaker: client_1
text: So, that's me. I flew that mission. "The Madrasah Murderer."

speaker: therapist
text: So, uh, do you, you surf the Net?

speaker: client_1
text: Well, somehow... Well, it wasn't really somehow. Let's call a spade a spade. A leak... probably another intelligence fuckup. Anyway, I was identified as the pilot in that mission, and my photo is placed on fundamentalist websites. And I'm not talking Al Jazeera, I'm talking websites that... asking for my head on a platter, offering up the heavens and the 40 virgins to anyone who will slit my throat from ear to ear.

speaker: client_1
text: Here, um... Here I am. Now, it's not a recent photo. It's a photo taken when I was 18, on a high school trip to... Europe... Holland.

speaker: therapist
text: That city with the miniatures?

speaker: client_1
text: Ultre... Utrecht.

speaker: therapist
text: Utrecht.

speaker: therapist
text: Go ahead.

speaker: client_1
text: So while I'm sitting here talking to you, a million fanatics are downloading my portrait and printing it out as a dartboard. Silly motherfuckers.

speaker: therapist
text: So, why have you come to see me?

speaker: client_1
text: Whoa whoa whoa whoa, we'll get to that. Now, so you're probably thinking... "What's it like?" He flew his mission, and he flew back. And he saw the bodies of those children on CNN. You're probably trying to figure out, "What went through his head?" Let me tell you. After that kind of mission, I don't watch CNN. I go to sleep. I'm dead tired. You're probably dying to ask how I can sleep nights.

speaker: client_1
text: How do you sleep?

speaker: client_1
text: I sleep very well, thank you very much. Knowing it was "mission accomplished". And with great precision, let me tell you. See, I followed my orders, which were: hit my target, and hit it on time. Time and target. Do you know we have to hit our targets within two seconds of the estimated time? It's surgical. That's one small window, and I have never missed it. If I had failed that task, I'd be in trouble with my superiors, with my conscience, and with the system. But I hit my target. So I sleep like a baby.

speaker: client_1
text: How many children died in this mission? The media puts it at sixteen. And the Navy, doctor. Listen. The Navy says nothing, and why should it? It's not in the business of body counts; it's about hitting our targets. We don't look back over our shoulder, believe me. We're out there doing our thing, so you can sit here in peace, talking to people for a living.

speaker: therapist
text: So, when did you hear the children had been killed?

speaker: client_1
text: The following afternoon. I heard it on the Internet.

speaker: therapist
text: And what exactly did you hear? Anything specifically that you remember?

speaker: client_1
text: It's not like there's time in the day to be surfing the Net. This was a moment. I got away. There's a lot of stuff to keep me busy. Mission review: aerial photos, videos. Just data, stuff. Preparation versus execution. Every tiny technical aspect of our flight is recorded and analyzed by the man. There's nowhere to hide. And that's the way it should be. It's just stuff and more stuff.

speaker: therapist
text: It's like when my mother died. My father had a year's worth of stuff to deal with: last will and testament, her office, garden, a lifetime of photo albums. And every time I'd talk to him and ask how he was, expecting he'd break down, he finally said, "It never ends, Alex. It never ends. Your mother left such a mess. She didn't know she was gonna die." And that's all he'd say. After less than a year, he met another woman and got married, just like that.

speaker: client_1
text: So, how did that make you feel? I was surprised. A whole life together and not a single tear.

speaker: client_1
text: How do you sleep?

speaker: client_1
text: I sleep very well, thank you very much. Knowing it was "mission accomplished". And with great precision, let me tell you. See, I followed my orders, which were: hit my target, and hit it on time. Time and target. Do you know we have to hit our targets within two seconds of the estimated time? It's surgical. That's one small window, and I have never missed it. If I had failed that task, I'd be in trouble with my superiors, with my conscience, and with the system. But I hit my target. So I sleep like a baby.

speaker: client_1
text: How many children died in this mission? The media puts it at sixteen. And the Navy, doctor. Listen. The Navy says nothing, and why should it? It's not in the business of body counts; it's about hitting our targets. We don't look back over our shoulder, believe me. We're out there doing our thing, so you can sit here in peace, talking to people for a living.

speaker: therapist
text: So, when did you hear the children had been killed?

speaker: client_1
text: The following afternoon. I heard it on the Internet.

speaker: therapist
text: And what exactly did you hear? Anything specifically that you remember?

speaker: client_1
text: How do you sleep?

speaker: client_1
text: I sleep very well, thank you very much. Knowing it was "mission accomplished". And with great precision, let me tell you. See, I followed my orders, which were: hit my target, and hit it on time. Time and target. Do you know we have to hit our targets within two seconds of the estimated time? It's surgical. So I sleep like a baby.

text: How many children died in this mission? The media puts it at sixteen. And the Navy, doctor. Listen. The Navy says nothing, and why should it? It's not in the business of body counts; it's about hitting our targets. We don't look back over our shoulder, believe me. We're out there doing our thing, so you can sit here in peace, talking to people for a living.

speaker: therapist
text: So, when did you hear the children had been killed?

speaker: client_1
text: The following afternoon. I heard it on the Internet.

speaker: therapist
text: And what exactly did you hear? Anything specifically that you remember?

speaker: client_1
text: It's not like there's time in the day to be surfing the Net. This was a moment. I got away. There's a lot of stuff to keep me busy. Mission review: aerial photos, videos. Just data, stuff. Preparation versus execution. Every tiny technical aspect of our flight is recorded and analyzed by the man. There's nowhere to hide. And that's the way it should be. It's just stuff and more stuff.

speaker: therapist
text: It's like when my mother died. My father had a year's worth of stuff to deal with: last will and testament, her office, garden, a lifetime of photo albums. And every time I'd talk to him and ask how he was, expecting he'd break down, he finally said, "It never ends, Alex. It never ends. Your mother left such a mess. She didn't know she was gonna die." And that's all he'd say. After less than a year, he met another woman and got married, just like that.

speaker: client_1
text: So, how did that make you feel? I was surprised. A whole life together and not a single tear.

speaker: therapist
text: It's interesting that you compare the death of your mother with this mission that you've just... flown. That's very clever of you. But there's no relation whatsoever. My mother's death was the most traumatic event in my life so far. That mission was just another mission for Alex. There is no comparison.

speaker: client_1
text: Anyway, look, that's over. And I'm back now. I'm back at my home base, and now I'm on R&R.

speaker: therapist
text: What kind of things do you do for R&R?

speaker: client_1
text: Don't try to get ahead of me. I'm a runner. I was a hell of a runner in high school and I'm still a pretty good one for an old man. So I run. With my fairy friend, this gay guy who could kick your ass at any sport.

speaker: therapist
text: And does he have a name, this friend?

speaker: client_1
text: Daniel.

speaker: therapist
text: We've been running together for a long time, between 6 and 10 miles... Depending on whether one of us is on his period.

speaker: client_1
text: Only this time I challenged him a little. There's no real good running in the Middle East. Not for the US military, unless you want a roadside bomb to blow your balls off. So I wanted to do some serious running. I said, "Let's go for 15." Then after 15 miles, I said, "20." Now he didn't want it, but I said, "Okay, I'll go on my own." So he followed. I said, "You know, only 6 more, it's a marathon. Let's do it." He wanted to stop. Little bitch. But I wasn't gonna stop. It was tough. We were out of water, we were on fumes. At 22 miles, I had a heart attack and died. A textbook case... Straight out of med school... Enlargement of the left ventricle. In accordance with the family history on both sides, fatal. According to the EKG and according to statistics, I had a 97.3% chance of dying, or 2.7% chance of living. Anyway... dead.

speaker: therapist
text: You actually died?

speaker: client_1
text: In the clinical sense. No pulse, no brain activity. Total clinical death.

speaker: client_1
text: But here I am. And now I'm gonna disappoint you, doctor. Don't you wanna know why I'm gonna disappoint you? Let me help you out. The light, the tunnel, the "whole life flashing before my eyes", that's what you're interested in, right? Hey, I couldn't give a shit about it either. But that's all everyone wanted to know about. My father, my wife... Just everyone. They just wanted to hear about the goddamn tunnel. Just -- such bullshit. Nobody really knows what was going through my mind during those last few moments. As soon as there was no more tunnel, no one was interested. Oh, I knew what was happening. You can tell. And you're afraid it's the end. In all that time, until I lost consciousness... All that time... I don't know how long it was - maybe seconds, maybe half a minute - all that time, I kept trying to figure out if I had a hard-on. See, I don't know how I remember this. Something my grandmother told me when I was in high school. And she said, when grandpa died, she found him lying naked in the bathtub with a huge erection. Now he -- he was 92 years old. She hadn't seen an erection like that in 20 years. She liked it. She said, that was "God's final gift to a man, a dead man's boner." They call it "angel lust." Anyway, so I'm lying there and I'm thinking about that story. I know what's happening to me, and I said to myself, "God almighty, just... don't let me have an erection right now, not a hard-on." Because, if you had an erection, it would mean that... That would mean that I was dead.

speaker: therapist
text: And your friend Daniel was with you throughout this? For a minute, I thought you were going to say something else, that perhaps your fear of an erection was associated with the presence of... your friend, Daniel. Maybe I didn't make myself clear earlier on, when I was talking about the customer always being wrong. What I meant was that sometimes the patient hides things from his therapist, from himself. And so part of our job is to uncover the things that we hide.

speaker: client_1
text: Excuse me? Don't you think you're exaggerating a little? I explained something simple: A dead man's erection. What's that gotta do with Daniel? So, so my secret is, I'm afraid of homosexuals? Yeah, okay. That's neither here nor there. I wanna get to my point. Go ahead. I didn't have the erection, so you can relax. But I remember very vividly that moment, just before passing out... before losing consciousness.

speaker: therapist
text: "Losing consciousness"... That's a funny expression. Why do you think that's a funny expression? "Losing" consciousness - it's an expression my father would use. Everything in terms of profits and loss. Fits him like a glove.

speaker: client_1
text: Okay, with all due respect, I think we've come to this way too early. All this stuff about the father-son relationship, I don't think it should come up so soon. I'm paying for this. And what do you expect to find, Alex? How are we going to know that I'm a good enough therapist for you? I'll know... according to your opinion. But I'll come to that in a minute. It has to do with what happened to me after taking me out of the freezer. They froze me in a suit for 48 hours, a record. I remember a terrible fatigue, mental exhaustion, and the relief I felt when I succeeded in coming back over into the world. Yet everyone was disappointed. I'm part of a military elite; we are born to excel.

speaker: therapist
text: So, if you don't supply the goods, then... Are you disappointed in yourself? Perhaps your anger isn't directed at those people who were interested in the tunnel, but you're angry at yourself, Alex, how your body betrayed you. This was a systems failure not supposed to happen to somebody like you.

speaker: client_1
text: Listen. I have a brother who's not too bright. He's a real estate agent. He once proved that all the great quarterbacks were the best-looking; it's evolutionary. Now I'm part of a military elite. Life chose us to be the best. At age seven or eight, you know you're headed somewhere special. I'm a TOPGUN grad. This training is not for pussies. So, if you don't achieve your personal best... Are you disappointed in yourself?

speaker: therapist
text: How much longer do we have? I'll tell you when it's time.

speaker: client_1
text: Okay, so here's my point, finally. I came here to get your advice on something. I decided to go back to the site where I dropped the bomb, to the Madrasah. I want to take a look around. I don't have a guilty conscience. I sleep well at night. Why would you want to go back? I'm interested. Daniel thinks it's crazy. He said I need to see someone first. Psychologist, psychiatrist. Don't you think it's dangerous? Not at all. I don't think anyone will recognize me. Not even my wife, Michaela.

speaker: therapist
text: Don't you talk things over with your wife? You're paying good money to see me. You expect to tell a perfect stranger the most intimate things about your life. There's risk here. What do you expect to find? I'll know according to my opinion of the issue you came to talk about. Let's go back to the freezer story.

speaker: client_1
text: No, literally frozen in a suit for 48 hours. It reduces shock to the body by dropping temperature. It's a record. I went a long way up that tunnel that wasn't there. I remember the fatigue, the relief, the will to live, yet everyone was disappointed. I have never spent a day in a hospital. Never.

speaker: therapist
text: It's not everyday people meet someone who's come back from the dead. I'm happy to see you again. Keep talking about this. We still have time next session.

speaker: client_1
text: Do they have any coffee around here? I could use a good cup of coffee. I better pay you now. Who knows how this little trip will turn out? Ain't you gonna wish me luck?

speaker: therapist
text: Yes. Good luck, Alex.
